citation.article-title: Thioreductor micantisoli gen. nov., sp. nov., a novel mesophilic, sulfur-reducing chemolithoautotroph within the epsilon-Proteobacteria isolated from hydrothermal sediments in the Mid-Okinawa Trough.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Thioreductor micantisoli sp. nov.
Thioreductor micantisoli (mi.can.ti.so′li. L. part. adj. micans -tis sparkling; L. gen. neut. n. soli of the floor; N.L. gen. n. micantisoli from the sparkling seafloor).
Cells are highly motile rods with a mean length of 2·0 μm and a width of about 0·5 μm.
NaCl in the concentration range 20–40 g l−l is an absolute growth requirement (optimum growth occurs at 25 g l−l).
Strictly chemolithoautotrophic growth occurs with molecular hydrogen as an electron donor and with elemental sulfur or nitrate as electron acceptor.
Elemental sulfur and nitrate are reduced to H2S and ammonium, respectively.
The major cellular fatty acids are C18 : 1 (65·6 %), C16 : 0 (22·4 %), C16 : 1 (5·1 %), 3-OH C14 : 0 (4·0 %) and C14 : 0 (2·9 %).
The G+C content of the genomic DNA is 37·2 mol% (HPLC).
Isolated from deep-sea hydrothermal sediments collected from Iheya North hydrothermal field in the Mid-Okinawa Trough, Japan.
